Posts.Title: Do any of you restrict certain foods? brandall SchnauzerMom

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2013 05:30AM ForestDweller wrote: Marty....it's not easy to come to terms with progression. You can still have a good summer. Xeloda is not easy. My doctor says its harsh but women chose it because of the convenience of pills and no hair loss. I became NED after three months on Xeloda but felt awful. I thought feeling awful was the price I had to pay. Well after three more months the cancer was back. After stopping Xeloda I came back to life though. Then we tried A/A...didn't work. Then the doc suggested Abraxane and I thought oh no it's all downhill from here and will have a rotten spring. Surprise......after 5 infusions I still feel normal and have plenty of energy to do all I want. I lost my hair but that's it. Why was I so scared? Because swallowing pills sounds less harsh than an IV drug. Don't dread what's in store for you....it may not be near as bad as you imagine.

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2012 07:29PM ForestDweller wrote: Cornell University did a study with 745 women who had breast cancer mets and found that those who ate the most dairy and protein had a significant lower risk of death. Fruit, veggies, vitamins and red meat consumption made no difference. So I've been eating lots of cheese, beef, milk, etc.  It seems to work so far.  NED for close to a year.  But like others have said, it's all a crap shoot.
Posts.Title: My Cancer Diet stagefree ShetlandPony

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2012 07:11AM ForestDweller wrote: Stagefree, I totally agree with you about having to do what's necessary to be able to live without regrets.  I did not want to try to talk you out of your diet choices.  On the other hand there are those women here who are not able to follow your diet, or are confused as to what the right diet is.  I thought it might ease their mind to see that there are different studies and viewpoints about this and that no one really knows what the right or wrong foods are. My oncologist has only ever mentioned three things about my diet:  cook everything, eat more meat, lose a few pounds. I was worried about the meat so I started googling cancer diets for stage IV and came across the Cornell study.  It eased my mind.  I am also glad that you have found a diet that you can feel good about and that works for you.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 10:38AM ForestDweller wrote: My HER2 changed from pos. to neg. and I got bone mets. I want to touch on the weight issue . My weight is 128 at 5'4" and if I go above 130 my oncologist starts to warn me. I was over 138 once and the PET scan showed fatty liver. I was told to lose weight or the liver would create a problem for me later. I don't want to be argumentative but drugs have never caused me to gain weight . Some of them make me want to eat everything in sight, but I don't do that. I noticed if I go above 1200 calories a day I gain. I'm sedentary that's why the low amount . Point is...it is possible to keep the weight down as a BC patient even when all I do is sit mostly.

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2014 07:45AM ForestDweller wrote: Lindsey....one day at a time.  That's how you and your family will go through this.  You can't start thinking about what's down the road for two weeks or two month from now. I've been in your parents place.  Both my husband and I battled cancer for the same five years.  I'm still battling and he lost his battle in May. For some parts of his treatment he had to be treated in another state.  We managed it all, including taking care of 40 acres in the country with large gardens and him chopping 10 ricks of firewood every winter with leukemia. For the first year our only son was in Afghanistan. We each drove the other to appointments only if absolutely necessary so that we wouldn't spend all our time sitting in waiting rooms.  People can drive themselves to chemo and back, unless your parents are real old and frail already. My most important piece of advice:  One day at a time.

Posts.Title: I've Been Deported... AmyQ curveball

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2015 10:21AM ForestDweller wrote: My husband was retired military and a veteran, so he had tricare and also qualified for VA care. I only have tricare so my VA experience has been through my husband's cancers. First of all I would wonder how much experience they have with breast cancer. I have spent lots of time in three VA oncology clinics in Arkansas and Tennessee and have never seen a female patient. The previous poster is correct with her assessment of the doctors,etc. One clinic didn't even have full time oncologists. They contracted with a civilian clinic and a doctor came by as needed. Nurse practitioners ran the show. They also had no idea that the MMR vaccine is a live virus vaccine. Every time that my husband was hospitalized for neutropenic fever he had a different doctor each day making rounds. He was sent to Nashville for a stem cell transplant for leukemia. The VA transplant clinic there is ran by Vanderbilt doctors and is top of the line. A few years later my husband got lung/esophageal cancer and started out with VA care again. Everything was so slow and disjointed that I was finally able to talk my husband into seeing my oncologist. Unfortunately the leukemia returned after starting treatments for the other cancers. No, I would not recommend the VA for cancer treatment, unless the clinic is connected with doctors from a major hospital like Vanderbilt. My son uses the VA for minor problems and he is not getting any kind of real help. Our neighbor, a civilian doctor, has diagnosed a knee problem that my son wants the VA to fix because it was caused by the military, but they are saying the problem doesn't exist.
Posts.Title: VA (Veterans Administration) scuttlers 3-16-2011

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2013 10:54PM ForestDweller wrote: I had a craniotomy two years ago and lived to tell you about it. It wasn't for a met though. It was to get infection from listeriosis out that I got from eating salads while being neutropenic. It really wasn't difficult at all. I woke up and was rolled into the ICU for three days. My bed had to stay at a certain angle with the head up to prevent headaches. Had to take steroids to prevent seizures. At one point three visitors snuck in at the same time and we talked so loud and laughed so hard that the nurse fussed at us and threw them out......lol. We still laugh about that now. It really wasn't bad at all.....except for the dirty bloody hair that I wasn't allowed to wash. I never had pain or any other discomfort but boredom.

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2013 10:08AM ForestDweller wrote: My oncologist had me lose 8-10 lbs. You can Google for a calorie calculator where you put your weight height and activity level in. It then calculates how many calories you need to maintain your weight. Then you simply eat less than that. I ended up eating around 850- 900 calories daily and lost a pound per week. The key is to keep track of everything you put into your mouth. Write down the calories for everything. You will be surprised how little you can eat. American portions are majorly out of control. Now I've been maintaining my weight for a year and a half by doing it the same way. Also weigh yourself at the same time every morning ....before or after breakfast. That way you will know if maybe your weight has krept up a pound before you have several pounds to lose again. It sounds tedious but it will become your way of life. It is something I have complete control over unlike the cancer so it makes me feel great when I step onto the scale at the cancer clinic.
